Posted By: RedAtrocitus (8/30/2012 7:40:25 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
@Lifegainwithbite  
  
I think "one of the best one-drops" at least needs the qualification that we're just talking standard here. It's seen a lot of play in standard lately, and rightly so, but it's **much** better in limited environments than it is anywhere else due to the "humans" requirement for its evasion. Outside of standard, that evasion becomes extremely unreliable, and RDW has quite a few better one-drops that have a either more consistent ways to get bigger or far scarier consequences for opponents unable to answer. I think a rating based purely on power of near 4 seems about right, though I'd think it'd be above, not below, and if we're taking into account *swagger* he clearly needs deserves a 5.
posts.html:
@Lifegainwithbite

I think "one of the best one-drops" at least needs the qualification that we're just talking standard here. It's seen a lot of play in standard lately, and rightly so, but it's much better in limited environments than it is anywhere else due to the "humans" requirement for its evasion. Outside of standard, that evasion becomes extremely unreliable, and RDW has quite a few better one-drops that have a either more consistent ways to get bigger or far scarier consequences for opponents unable to answer. I think a rating based purely on power of near 4 seems about right, though I'd think it'd be above, not below, and if we're taking into account swagger he clearly needs deserves a 5.

posts.post_content:
One of the best one drops is a 3.8/5?... Why?   
@Anstache: Not just in standard. The first ability is just the icing on the cake. Stromkirk gets stronger every turn regardless. It's a great one drop for any red aggro deck. True, in modern [Goblin Guide](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name= Goblin Guide) is better but you could run Stromkirk alongside it. It still has some relevancy in modern (although yes I was talking about standard in the best one drops thing).

Posted By: RetroGamer3 (12/3/2012 5:00:14 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Assault strobe, Curse of Stalked Prey, Artful Dodge, Apostle's Blessing, Rakish Heir  
  
With so many neat spells to help him get trough and get nasty quickly i always wondered why he didnt appear in standard more often.  
  
T1: Him  
T2: Curse of Stalked Prey. Opponent at 19, him 3/3.  
T3: Assault Strobe, Artful Dodge. Opponent at 11, him 7/7. Mana open for Apostle protection.  
T4: Assault Strobe, flashback the dodge. Opponent at -5 (aka, enough damage so that even some life gain wont matter).  
This does require two Assault strobes, but even with just one he will be a serious threat early on.  
  
Oh, and how come all the instants/sorceries starts with "a"?
posts.html:
Assault strobe, Curse of Stalked Prey, Artful Dodge, Apostle's Blessing, Rakish Heir

With so many neat spells to help him get trough and get nasty quickly i always wondered why he didnt appear in standard more often.

T1: Him
T2: Curse of Stalked Prey. Opponent at 19, him 3/3.
T3: Assault Strobe, Artful Dodge. Opponent at 11, him 7/7. Mana open for Apostle protection.
T4: Assault Strobe, flashback the dodge. Opponent at -5 (aka, enough damage so that even some life gain wont matter).
This does require two Assault strobes, but even with just one he will be a serious threat early on.

Oh, and how come all the instants/sorceries starts with "a"?

I play this and [Assault Strobe](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Assault Strobe) in my RDW deck. So terribly boss.  
  
The question is, if you give it double strike while it's still a 1/1, and it deals direct damage, does it deal a total of three damage or two? I know it still gets two +1/+1, but does it get a +1/+1 during the first strike damage and then another after regular?
